title: Is music still copyright after the artist dies? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes, usually. At this time, anything published before 1923 is in the public domain. Anything published after 1978 is copyrighted for the life of the author/composer/etc/ plus seventy years. If published between 1923 and 1978, it is for the life of the creator plus 95 years or 120 years from the date of publication, whichever comes first. Look in the FAQs at this site for more detailed information: U.S. Copyright Office

Yes. In most countries, the artist’s copyright expires 50 or 75 years after the artist’s death (depending on the country). In the US, the copyright situation is more complicated. There are various exceptions, but it’s safe to assume that everything published in the US since 1923 is still under copyright there. If the artist is no longer alive, copyright goes to his or her estate and heirs.
